annotation_sentence: Oh, hi Wing! It was very nice. I enjoy... um, the city a lot. Many thing to see.
rationale: The phrase 'a lot' is a quantifier indicating a large amount, and 'Many' is a quantifier indicating a large number of things.

annotation_sentence: Uh, I go to the big... um, how to say... the clock tower. Very famous.
rationale: The word 'big' is a quantifier indicating a large size.

annotation_sentence: Yes, Big Ben! It is very, very tall. I take many photo.
rationale: The word 'many' is a quantifier indicating a large number of photos.

annotation_sentence: Yes, I try the fish and chips. Very tasty, but... how to say... a bit oily.
rationale: The phrase 'a bit' is a quantifier indicating a small amount.

annotation_sentence: Yes, British Museum! I see many artifact... very interesting.
rationale: The word 'many' is a quantifier indicating a large number of artifacts.

annotation_sentence: Um, a little. The subway... very crowded. But I use map on phone, so okay.
rationale: The phrase 'a little' is a quantifier indicating a small amount.

annotation_sentence: Yes, I go to the... um, big park with lake and many bird.
rationale: The word 'big' is a quantifier indicating a large size, and 'many' is a quantifier indicating a large number of birds.

annotation_sentence: Yes, I meet some traveler from other country. We talk... um, about trip and share story.
rationale: The word 'some' is a quantifier indicating an unspecified amount.

annotation_sentence: Yes, I want to go again. So much more to see. Maybe next year!
rationale: The word 'much' is a quantifier indicating a large amount, and 'more' is a comparative quantifier indicating an additional amount.
